text: 650ml bottle from phesterjau, cellared 16 months had side by side with XX, and shared by all during ck1 birthday trip. Thanks Jess! Sweet thick malts. Big barrel. Smooth. Excellent! 16.7

Bottle at tasting. Dark pour. Aroma of red fruit, vanilla, milk chocolate, caramel fudge and cherry. Taste has milk chocolate, bourbon vanilla, raisin, booze, nuts, ripe fruit and a long lasting finish. I expected something amazing and got what I wanted.

650 ml bottle, shared 3 ways. Pitch black color, thin tan head. Aroma shows me roasted malts, vanilla, light bourbon, brandy notes, cream, milk chocolate, plum notes, some biscuits.
Flavor is just wonderful. Moderate bourbon throughout the sip, vanilla, brownie batter hints. The sip ends on toffee and some oak. Honestly, every time I take a sip I get a combination of different flavors. The complexity of this is high. The alcohol is damn near completely hidden. This one will sneak up on you. Delightful.

Bomber from AFH. Thanks so much dude! Split 3 ways. Fridge temp and warmed up in stemware.

A - This is a dark brown to black beer, 1 finger big bubbly head. 

S - Smells incredible. Figs, raisin, vanilla, coconut, cocoa, fudge, 

T - Holy moly. MMMMM YEAH. This is a bourbon fudge bomb. Sweet, not really boozy. Finish is coconut.

M - Very thick, its like a syrupy malt bomb barleywine. 

O - I know my rate here is weak. but its the last beer of the evening but this is fantastic. Delicious.

Deep, almost opaque reddish black beer, almond colored head. Aroma is roasting malt, raisin, vanilla, molasses, cookies, figs. Taste is malt, coffee, vanilla, cookies, toast, raisin, fig, cola. Paler is smooth and rich, carbonation average, holding up well. Super beer.

On tap. Pours a dark brown with very light head. Aromas of brown sugar, raisins, bourbon and sweet toasted malts. Rich flavors of same, very much chewy bourbon raisins on a sweet malt base with light nutty chocolate. Yummy.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown black color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy woody caramel dark fruit vanilla aroma. Fruity malty woody vanilla chocolate caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty woody caramel vanilla dark fruit finish.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2017 Pours dark brown with some nearly tan head. Nose is big with toffee and caramel. Bourbon is the next most noticable scent. I?m also getting dates and maybe a hint of brandy. Taste is equally big. Lots of toffee and molasses. Bourbon and brandy are both present. Vanilla, raisin, leather and tobacco round out the taste. Moderate alcohol burn on the way down. Each sip reveals something new. Full bodied, sticky, almost chewy. This is a lovely, lovely beer.

Black with a light beige head. Aroma is chocolate, bourbon, malt, dark fruits. Full bodied, sticky mouthfeel, sweet and boozy on the palate with a slightly nutty finish. Taste is chocolate, bourbon, sesame seed, malt.
Bottle - pours dark brown white head - nose/taste of bourbon, toffee, caramel, oxidized notes - medium body

Pours deep mahogany into a tulip. Mocha head with medium retention recedes to nothing. Dark pit fruit, vanilla, bourbon and oak aromas. Medium bodied with hot, alcohol soaked raisins and pit fruit upfront turning to chocolate and soy in the lasting finish.
From a 22 oz. bottlle it is a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is toffee, and the taste is Sweet and boozy yummy
From a 22 oz. bottle. Pours a cola brown with a tan head. Flavors of toffee, caramel and prunes. Sweet and boozy but very tasty.

22 oz. bottle, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is decadent, with loads of bourbon and vanilla upfront, followed by treacle, caramel and a touch of liqueur. Flavour is no less impressive, with tons of bourbon and vanilla, followed by caramel, treacle, a touch of cocoa and more bourbon. Amazingly deep, with a warming finish. Phenomenal stuff.

Thanks to Brian for this great treat! Partagée en compagnie de Guillaume et Yan. Majestueuse robe sombre aux couleur de caramel, de tabac à pipe, de vieux scotch. Mousse épique pour une bière de cette force. Cette dernière maccompagne tout au long du processus de dégustation sans jamais baisser la tête. Arômes de caramel, dun alcool qui ne me déplaît pas, de canne à sucre, de rhum, de barley wine. Cest en effet cette composante qui lemporte sur le stout, malgré sa forte teneur en Parabole, ce stout de renommée mondiale. Un orge cru, craquant, riche, étincelant. Cest plein de vie et de sagesse. En bouche je note des arômes de caramel, de crème brûlée, de bois vanillé, le tout enrobé dans un alcool puissant du Sud. Très chaude dans loesophage, cette bière me plaît, comme toutes les autres bières de cette brasserie que jaime tant!

650 ml bottle. Thanks veliemboys! Pours a dark brown colour without a head. Aroma of sweet bread, bourbon, wood and some vanilla fudge. Flavour of strong sweet malts, bourbon, vanilla fudge, mild floral notes, bitterness and some dried fruits. Full bodied. Long warming finish. Elegant, as always.

65 cl bottle.
Pours clear dark ruby red color with a small head. Very intoxicating aroma with caramel malts, toffee, faint hops, dried ripe fruits, wooden notes, vanilla, bourbon-y. Flavor has vanilla and toffee, raisins, licorice notes, subtle spices, caramel malt sweetness, some bourbon. Finish is sweet n sticky, alcohol is well hidden, raisins get stronger as the warms up. Very pleasant and complex. Super.
5327

650ml bottle from Firestone Walker Venice. Pours dark brown, almost black with a small head. Aroma of raisins, bourbon, wood, oak, vanilla, toffee, syrup, hints of brandy, mustard, ripe fruits and mild roastiness. Taste is sweetish, complex and slightly syrupy with some bourbon, wood, vanilla, oak, toffee, mild roastiness, ripe fruits, raisins and chocolate and coffee. Complex and heavy, but perhaps the raisin and quad-like notes from Stickee Monkee dominate a bit too much.

65 cl bottle @ olio
Aroma has sweet bourbon tones with vanilla. Also mustard(!). Flavour has bourbon, vanilla, mustard-like tones and mild spicy tones. Warming alcohol. A slow sipper.

Shared bottle at Craft Tuesday share. Poured hazy blackish brown with tan head. Nose was dark malt, dark choc, oak, spirits, molasses. Tasted rich, dark malty, with notes of oaky spirits, dark fruit, dark malt, and a complex and dense finish.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2017 A bottle on Black Christmas 2016 at 12 Kings. Pours a dark reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, bourbon. Taste is pretty the same with moderate sweetness. Very good.

Bottle thanks to Tyler. Pours murky brown with a tan head. Coffee, molasses, anise, construction paper. Average carbonation, very sweet. I love how prominent Sucaba and stickee monkey is in this blend on the flavors.

On tap at Flying Saucer on the lake. Black with a small tan head. Aroma is of heavy oak, bourbon, vanilla, molasses, chocolate. Taste is of bourbon, oak, fudge, chocolate, vanilla bean, molasses, and maple.
Tap. Started too cold but blossomed as it warmed. The smell is a unique blend of whiskey, oak, fruit, caramel, toffee. Good stuff. The taste is rich, chocolate, fruit, wood, alcohol, and good stuff.
Bottle shared by a friend. Dark brown pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma of malt, booze and caramel. Malty and caramelly flavor with some booze before a syrupy, old IPA finish.

Jet black pour with a thin espresso colored head. Aroma is big time chocolate and cocoa. A little bit of barrel character as well as some chocolate and vanilla. You can taste individual components of the blended beers in this, but together they are fantastic. Love these cuvees.

Bottle shared by a friend. Poured a deep dark Brown colour with atanned head. Nose if clear parabola upfront. Deep sweet bourbon notes, vanilla, caramel, toasted malts, pralines chocolate, light charred smoke, dark fruits. Sweet sticky finish. Very Nice blend

Bottle shared thanks to RandomStrangerNL. Dark brown wih a ring tan head. Aroma of huge bourbon, vanilla, oak barrel, butterscotch, toffee, caramel and malt. Flavour is heavy sweet. Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle thanks to Rick. Pours a dark brown with medium beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is strong caramel, raisin, wood, bourbon. Medium body, burnt sugar, caramel, wood, vanilla, nice sweetness, boozy finish, very nice.

Bottle shared by RandomStrangerNL at Klooster Delft. Big sweet roasted malts. Big alcoholic, dades, dark fruit. Big sweet, light bitter. Over medium body. Soft carbonation, big malty feel. Bittersweet fruity finish.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2016 Bottle shared at Klooster. Dark ruby-brown pour with a thin tan head. Notes of bourbon, toffee, toasted coconut, vanilla, oak, cherries. Medium body, low carbonation and a bourbon bitter-sweet finish.

Bottle shared thanks to RandomstrangerNL. Very dark brown with short lasting beige head. Massive bourbon, sweet chocolate, quite some spices, alcohol warmth, marzipan, walnuts, cognac. Quite sweet with some alcoholic bitterness. Over medium bodied with slick feel and some alcohol in the finish.
Aroma is filled with alcohol -bourbon. Taste is strong but smooth. Lots of roasted nuts and alcohol and smoke flavor. Enjoyable.
Draft. Smoother than the 18 ironically. Maltier slightly less complex which i guess ends uo helping it.

Bottle shared thanks to Sleepydave ! Pours a deep burnt umber color with two fingers of khaki foam. Layers of leather, cocoa dusted caramel, some dried fruit, soft handed booze and straight decadence. Note quite as complex as some past anniversaries but also had this without age, served slightly chilled and after a lot of sour beers.

Bottle from the cellar I think it came from Berts
Murky cloudy dark brown with a minimal head even with a firm pour down the center. Rich roasty deep caramel and dark fruits offset with a very nice coconut vanilla oakiness and bits if bourbon and brandy, They really do blend a great anniversary beer!
22oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a bit of beige head. Slight burnt brown sugar flavors and nice hop bitterness. A little hot.

650 mL bottle. Deep brown body with a small khaki head. Heavy nutty malt aroma. Hefty oak and some bourbon. Tastes of caramel, brown sugar, and oak. Lots and lots of oak. Brandy seems stronger than bourbon up front, but vanilla and bourbon come through behind. Really sweet. Heavy, but dry. Another struggle to get through, but also tasty.

bottle poured into a snifter..jet black..with a medium brown head..wonderful
aroma of bourbon,chocolate,coffee,leather,tobacco,brownies & malted milk..
tastes of all the former..boozy but smooth...another winner from FW.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2016 Bottle @ home. Big thanks to one of my trade partners -I forgot who sent me this Im sorry!- for sending me this! Bottle @ home. Opaque very dark brown color, medium sized light brown head that lasts for a decent while. Aroma is malts, caramel, chocolate, oak, wood, bourbon, brandy, ripe dark fruits, brandy or rum soaked raisins, vanilla. Holy shit this is heavy and incredibly complex! Taste malts, chocolate, a little less vanilla fortunately as I dont like a beer to have too much vanilla, lots of liquor: bourbon, brandy, wood, sweetness from the barrel as well as bitterness, a medium to firm alcohol burn in the finish. Raisins, overripe dark fruits, bourbon and brandy soaked dark fruits. Full body, medium to full carbonation (at least thats what the mouthfeel is like probably due to the alcohol burn). Im beginning to wonder whether I should have started -and will have to finish- this bomber on my own...[5 mins later, conversation with myself]...Shit I shouldnt have started this on my own. But I can still save some and put it in the fridge...Just recap the bottle and youll be fine...tomorrows another day to drink awesome beer. Why not spread the joy over two days? You know when you finish the bottle youll be drunk as hell. -Yes I know- Ah you finally speak. Good for you. Youve got about 5 sips left in your glass. Why not leave it at that, leave the rest of it in the bottle and cuddle your wife in bed? -Well, shes asleep already so whats the point?- Come on, she loves when you come to bed in time and cuddle for a bit. -But the fire isnt done yet.- Screw the fire! Itll die out eventually. Finish your glass and go to bed. -But theres a bunch of cheese that I bought which hasnt been eaten yet!- Screw the cheese, think of your wife. -I am thinking of her, shes asleep very sound, so why should I leave the fire and beer and potentially wake her up?- She wants you to be there with her, dont you get it? -Not really, I tried to show some affection earlier but she pushed me away because shes having her period!- Are you sure dude? -Wait what are you implying?- Cant you see? Youre always there on your own, ticking beers by the fire place. -Yeah, so? She doesnt like staying up late and she doesnt care about a nice fire. I like a nice fire and some good beer to go with it. Whats your problem?- Im gonna stop this conversation right here, right now! -Why?- Youre drunk! -No Im not!- Yes you are! (...) ○}●[□{》#,#&$, --- Next morning Im like: wtf babe, me been nice to ya all evening, what the problem?? --- Shit, no recollection, shouldnt have drunk this bottle on my own. Lesson learned? Not even close. But I am off to buy some flowers. Probably lots of flowers.

Bottle. Pours out a darker cola color with a small to moderate white head. Aroma is of lots of oak, brownie mix, bourbon, caramel, toffee, syrupy toasty malt, coconut. Taste is complex, lots of caramel, toasted coconut, dark chocolate, syrupy sweetness, oak, brownie mix, bourbon, alcohol, brandy, earth. Geez this is good and although the abv is high, it is silky smooth
Shared bottle at Aarons from Jasons vertical. Boozy chocolate barrel goodness. Great blend.

Another amazing beer from Firestone Walker. Pours a super thick, deep black with a tan head. Smells of brandy, raisin, vanilla and chocolate. Taste is brandy soaked raisin, chocolate covered cherries and more brandy in the finish. Had on tap at the brewery.

This was fricken awesome. I'm a big Bourbon County Stout fan and this was right at the same level. VERY good!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at CBC2016, Copenhagen. Colour is clear brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Dry fruits, wood, chocolate, dryness and malts. Great. This was actually 18 xvii change.

Pours brown with a minimal tan head. Aroma is oak, refined molasses, vanilla & maybe some faint coconut. Taste is smooth vanilla, caramel, milk chocolate & bourbon. The flavors keep transforming and melding and......Awesome!
Poured a light brown with a very minimal head. Aroma wad big vanilla barrel, booze, caramel, dark fruit, chocolate. Flavor similar, sweet but not cloying boozy delicious barrel juice.

22 oz bottle- Pours mostly black to almost brown with a thin light tan head. Aroma is barreled goodness, charred oak, toasted coconut, vanilla, toffee, classic FW BA aromas here. The taste is toasted coconut, bourbon, toffee, vanilla, the alcohol for how high it is is extremely well hidden, rich and chewy. This beer is fantastic, no flaws, phenomenal actually, but seems somehow redundant compared to years past, these Firestone Walker BA beers are starting to blend together for me, again fantastic beer though.

Bottle courtesy of Chris. Pours reddish caramel brown with a small pale mocha head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty, nutty and boozy with caramel, toffee, vanilla fudge, charred wood, roasted coconut, hazelnuts, brazil nuts, moist soil, bourbon alcohol and hints of green chili and sweet soy sauce. Taste is sweet, bitter, malty and slightly boozy. Mouthfeel is viscous, creamy, round, tiny cloying, slightly astringent, boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with caramel/toffee/vanilla fudge malts, assorted caramelized nuts and plenty of peppery bourbon barrel booze. Smell is mostly hot bourbon but the taste and mouthfeel offers almost everything youd expect from a FW anniversary blend. Way too hot at the moment but hopefully Ill get the chance to revisit in a year or so.

Bottle shared at kickbacks. Pours a clearish copper brown color. No head. Aromas of vanilla, dark fruits, caramel, rum. Taste is sweet and boozy. Candied raisins. Rum cake. Deliciousness. Definitely a sipper.
On tap. With a ginger cookie, ultra experience! Heavy on the tongue, but pleasant! Complex, fascinating. Something quite different.

Thanks Darrell. 

Dark chestnut body with a thin beige collar. Aromas of bourbon, oak, malt, light spice, brown sugar, caramel. Similar complexity in the flavor. Medium sweetness with warming alcohol heat throughout. Best shared with several people.

Bottle. Black pour with a medium, frothy brown head. Aroma is boozy with vanilla, caramel, roasted malt, light chocolate, and dark fruit notes. Taste is rich with chocolate, dark fruit, caramel, vanilla, molasses, roasted malt notes, light coffee and candy. Body is medium-full with a soft, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more chocolate, caramel, vanilla, candy, dark fruit notes, booze and molasses. Very nice!

Pours a dark brown with light head. A mild sweet malt and alcohol aroma. A strong taste of fruity malts, caramel, light chocolate and roasted coffee, caramel, toffee, and dark alcohol. A lingering sweet malt and alcohol aftertaste.

Bottle at Row 34, Portsmouth, NH. In the world of beer I love, Firestone Walkers barrel aged stuff is right up at the top, so I was very excited for this one and it did not disappoint. One of the most complex beers Ive ever tasted -- the beers that went into this blending are all noticeable, although the Parabola dominates a little. Strong tastes of chocolate and a bit of roasted coffee give way to malt sweetness and ripe fruit taste, before it all finishes with booze. A lot of booze. Itll be interesting to see how this matures, but at 3 months old its an orgy of flavor -- lots of chocolate and malt, lots of booze, and oh-so-enjoyable.
A: Dark dark brown with a light off white head that foes away fast. N: Booze, toffee, caramel, port T: caramel, booze and booze O: Very boozy. Some bitterness and caramel. Too hardcore for me.

Bottle. Dark brown beer with a tan head. Bourbon and chocolate aroma with light fruitiness. Bourbon and dark fruit flavor with caramel. Medium-plus bodied. Bourbon and chocolate linger with caramel and dark fruit.

From notes. 22 oz bottle shared by Doug at his house on February 22. The pour is a light black, a little thin, with a thin beige head that disappears very quickly, leaving a couple spots of lace as it falls to a thin collar. The aroma is heavily boozy. This reminds me of Parabola, which is a whiskey bomb. There is a little bit of oak in there and a light chocolate. There is a hint of molasses and a hint of licorice. Its not too bad, but I cant really get over the booziness. The flavors are very similar. There is a heavy whiskey up front and a bright woody char There is a nice caramel and a little sweet malt that blends with the molasses and chocolate nicely. On the bitter front, there is a hint of the licorice that remains present just like in the nose. The mouth feel is excellent. Its thick and viscous with a soft carbonation and a beautiful lingeringly boozy chocolate finish. I was skeptical on this one at first, but it really pulled together and turned into an excellent beer. This one definitely isnt as complex as XVIII, but I look forward to the next one!

Rating #2100. When in doubt for a milestone, go with a Firestone Walker Anniversary beer, thats my motto. Boxed bomber. Right after the first pour the aroma contains some astringent bourbon and oak. The astringency dissipates almost immediately, leaving coconut, toffee, chocolate, licorice, molasses, soy sauce--typical for this series, but thats never a bad thing. Pours dark dark brown to nearly black with a quickly collapsing beige head. Taste is sweet and savory with all those aroma deScriptors, along with some tobacco, leather; alcohol is strong, but its not boozy. Oily mouthfeel, full body. Super good, but maybe not as good as 14 or 16. Seems like a safe blend for the series. Very conservative. I expect the 20th Anniversary edition to be opposite of conservative. At least, I hope so.

22 oz bottle. Dark brown with beige suds. Nose is wood, whiskey, caramel, light cocoa and char. Medium body with a tang and a burn from the alcohol. Taste is caramel, more rum notes than bourbon, dark roast, coconut and raisin. Always top notch brews in their anniversary series.

On tap at Beer Baron. It pours a very dark brown color with deep reddish highlights. A thin ring of light tan foam around the edges of the glass. The aroma has some nice butterscotch, caramel and bourbon barrel notes. Big toffee and cocoa. The flavor has lots of spirits barrel with more cocoa, caramel, minor fig notes with a little smoke in the finish. Very rich on the palate. The spirits barrel dominates the flavor. Fig, caramel and more cocoa in the finish. Ok, but not one of the better FW anniversary beers. This one may actually benefit from some aging.

Bomber from Capitol Beer in Sacramento, CA. Pours brown with a slight foamy tan head. Aroma of dark sweetish chocolate, and lots of bourbon. Near full bodied. Flavor is chocolate, bourbon and dark fruits - sort of raisin more than date. There is detectable heat. :) Which is just another flavor component. With reflection wood and leather are also detectable. This is complex tasty stuff. Oh that my body could tolerate this constantly.

Pitch-black pour with a shy layer of foam that fizzes away into a mocha ring. Fruity, chocolatey aroma of dark chocolate, caramel pralines, prunes, graham crackers, vanilla, eggnog, a touch of licorice, and sultanas. The booze is plentiful enough to never lose sight of the fact that this is a near-14% abv beer. The taste is sweet, with moderate boozy/roasty bitterness and prominent chocolate and tarry flavors. Engaging, but too hot to be optimally enjoyed.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a minimal tan head. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, and dark fruit. Taste is bourbon, chocolate, barrel, dark fruit, caramel malt, and some vanilla. Exceptional.
On draft at the Blue monkey FW Tap Take over. Nose of sugar, coconut and plum. Full body with smooth velvet tastes of chocolate, wood, vanilla, coconut roast, Earth and whiskey. AWESOME.

Bottle @ Home. Sort of a cola colored beer with some tan foam. Typical barrel and booze forward beer here, which is pretty much fine with me in the case of these Firestone blends. A lot of creamy chocolate, brandy, raisin, and plum. Maybe a little bit of a dry, charred oak character. Lots of vanilla sweetness along with some caramel and brown sugar. Its a nice beer certainly, but happy to split the bottle with a few friends.
Pitch black and viscous. Big aroma of bourbon and chocolate. Flavor is all bourbon and booze, with chocolate and caramel notes. Chewy and full. Damn.

From a bottle. Pours dark murky brown with a fizzy tan head. Tastes like sweet dark dried fruits, caramel malt, chocolate, booze, and some earth. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like dried dark fruits, earthy, boozy, and sweet chocolate syrup.

Bottle from brewery. Pours deep, dark brown. Aroma is molasses, caramel,dark fruit, vanilla, oak, and faint tobacco. Flavor matches the aroma and is nicely layered with rich wood, dark fruit, and tobacco notes. Medium/full body.
Bottle shared by sonnycheeba. Pours an opaque black with a thin ring of beige head. Aroma and taste of some booze, roasted malts, dark chocolate, wood, hints of vanilla. So tasty and smooth.

Bottle @ Steasys. Thanks for sharing! Deep amber pour with a small head. Rich nutty malt. Plenty of toffee. Sweet and somewhat earthy. Old leather. Flavor of toasted bread, cocoa. Some dark fruit preserve. Fat profile, definitely a sipper. Good, but not at the level of FWs best work.
Pours. Lack with a light jead. Smells like a quad. Has a lot of sugar and alcohol taste with plum and grape. Somehow it has a very smooth palate despite the strength.

22 oz bottle purchased at RJs Wine and Spirits a few months ago. Deep reddish-brown appearance with a small tan head, fully dissipating. Rich, enticing aroma with notes of caramel malt, vanilla, cocoa, toasted oak, fruity esters, chocolate, wood and toffee. Similar flavor, decadent, rich, smooth and creamy. Full body with soft carbonation and a complex, lasting finish. A fantastic blend of some of their best beers. An amazing, awesome brew overall. Top 10.
On tap at Local Option. Poured black with min off white head. Aroma sweet boozy bourbon caramel. Light carb med bod. Quite sweet taste malty burnt sugar barrel heavy.

Bottle pours with a clear mahogany colored body that supports a wafer thin light tan head. The modest aroma offers up roasted malts, molasses, some brown sugar, bourbon like booze, chocolate more booze and some oak. The taste delivers similar notes such as molasses, molasses nuanced vanilla and smooth bourbon. It picks up sticky sweet oak and booze midway and into the finish. Pretty nice but it lacks the depth and character of a few of the other years. Maybe a year on the shelf will pull it together.
Amazing. Aroma is coconut and maybe carmel. Black draft pour with white head at local option. Thick. Boozy, coconut, chocolate, and slight fruit flavor. Rich and delicious

Bottle. First ever FW Anniversary beer and this was superb! Poured a deep, dark brown with a small bubbly off-white head. Amora of spirits and barrel aging, chocolate, caramel, coffee, molasses, earth. Flavor followed the nose and the barrel aging was super smooth, chocolaty, caramel, coffee bits, wood, some leather, earth. Complex and smooth describe this perfectly. Full body, slick texture, soft carbonation, and smooth and easy finish for such a big beer. Loved it!

Draft at Yardhouse in Houston. Pours dark brown with small tan head. Aroma island up front flavor is strong of bourbon barrels. Underlying ale is malty and complex. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, served at a party with imperfect notes. Pours cloudy mahogany, medium tan head with good lacing. Aroma is boozy, chocolate, molasses, bourbon, vanilla. Flavor follows, super rich, fairly sweet with light plus bitterness, full of cocoa, molasses, vanilla, dried dark fruits. Medium plus body, creamy mouthfeel. A fair bit of ABV heat.

651 ml. bottle. Pours a thin, well retained, beige head with no lacing over a clear effervescent, copper brown (SRM 22) body.......nose is dried fruits, with plum, raisin, light fig notes, also bourbon, vanilla from the barrel, light molasses, tobacco, hints of cocoa, no hops......taste is quite sweet with brown sugar notes, dried fruits including, plum, fig, raisin, also hints of cocoa, Bourbon throughout, with light vanilla, light tobacco, minimal hops......mouth feel, heavy sticky body, moderate alcohol heat (considering the ABV), slight acid. This is a huge, rich, heavy, sweet, highly complex, and very alcoholic beer. Any one who is not an aficionado of this type/style will be overwhelmed. It is a great beer for winter, and would be awful on a hot day. If one likes hops, stay away, as this is every thing but. BJCP 9/3/16/3/7

4 oz pour on draft at ChurchKey. Dark brownish black with light tan head. Aromas of bourbon, vanilla, dark chocolate, roasty notes. Tastes of big marshmallow and vanilla, bourbon, dark chocolate, subtle dark fruit. Full body with a dry finish. Very delicious, alcohol is well masked.

Draft at Churchkey. Deep clear maroon brown color, big beige head with good retention and solid lacing. Aroma has vanilla, port wine, butterscotch, plums, raisins. Taste is sweet, boozy dark fruit with an edge of vanilla and whiskey. Delicious. But sit close to the floor.
Draft - Sweet raisin, date and toffee. Deep jet brown with a rich brown head. Really sweet raisin and date with dark sugars and some barrel notes. A bit too sweet and fruity. Bottle may be better.

Tap at barrelworks, buellton. Almost black color, brown head. Fantastic aroma has oak, bourbon, chocolate, some coffee. Balanced rich body has oak, chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, hint of bourbon. Just excellent.

Bottle shared by Brian, thanks! Pours a clear deep amber with a touch of orange and a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice bourbon note with some sweet grains and a touch of molasses. Flavor has sweet grains and molasses with supporting notes of bourbon and toffee.

Aroma: Bourbon, boozy. 
Appereance: darkest ale ever. 
Taste: solid, wish I had left this in the shelf for a year. 
Palate: exceptional for such a young beer. 
Overall: will seek this out again and be more disciplined about leaving it on the shelf to age.

Bottle from Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head and a treacle and bourbon aroma. There is a full-bodied dark molasses flavor with a warm alcohol trail. This is a nice blend of four barrel-aged beers with a lot of chocolate and a lot of alcohol. A perfect sipper.

Dungeon red color. Thick, bubbley tan head that collapses quickly. Lacing okay. Nutty, bready aroma. There is something sweet in the aroma. Maybe raspberries. Caramel. Dark chocolate. There is some alcohol flavors. Not to overpowering for the percentage. Lively carbonation. Sticky texture. Long drawn out finish. I taste cherries. Great beer.
No surprise really - flipping fantastic. Rich, velvety smooth with the wonderful house barrel character and greater than expected complexity and smoothness. Best since 15.

Bomber. Dark brown pour topped with a dense layer of mocha foam. Strong notes of dark sugars, chocolate liqueur, bourbon barrel and tobacco in the aroma. Taste is bittersweet chocolate syrup, vanilla and toffee upfront with a bit of toasted oak, espresso and bourbon toward the end. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with low carbonation and a final shot of charred malt and whiskey in the finish. As expected, a greatest hits of FWs best BA brews.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2015 On tap in Los Angeles. Rich sweet dark ale, little roast or bitterness. The BDS and RIS are main in the blend, that shows. Massive whiskey coming through from the barrel aging. Great winter sipper.

Like a beautiful Creme brûlée, with the crisp brown sugar and heavy vanilla over the smooth, silky body. There is a long spicy booze that lingers but is never harsh or overwhelming. This is truly the only series of beers worth this kind of money.
Bottle shared at Steazys - thanks Brian! Dark brown pour with a slight tan head. Nose is toffee and caramel. Really nice taste, super toffee and burnt sugar. Yummy.
Bomber shared by Bvery, thanks buddy! Dark brown caramel pour. Strong caramel boozy sweetness aroma. Taste follows, really good.
Bottle. Deep murky reddish brown pour. Toffee, wood, vanilla. Some booze heat. Rich and delicious. Yummy.
Bomber in box with papers. Aroma is fig newton. Taste is caramel, toffee raisin. The sticky monkey comes through much more than the stouts.
Smell is pretty malty with some mineral. Taste is heavy malt, caramel, raisin, mineral, and booze. Medium body, medium carbonation, mild foam, and mild booze heat.
Draft. Dark pour with no head. Roasted, chocolate, boozy aromas. Flavors still not melding right, will look to try this with some age, boozy and chocolate and bourbon tones fighting right now.

Pours an amber brown with a khaki head. Bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, molasses, raisin, date, caramel, leather, tobacco, oak and alcohol aroma and flavors. Full body and moderate carbonation with a chocolate, molasses and bourbon finish.

Black pour under a thin off white cap. Amazing nose with a sweet bourbon and plum/raisin nose with some brown sugar and cherry and vanilla and oak. Big Oaked and boozy flavor with boozy bittersweet chocolate, sweet bourbon, lots of plum and raisin, boozy oak and bourbon notes, sweet but boozy and chocolate and whiskey tones all over the place. A bit more on the quad side of things, but lovely all the same.

Bottle at the parentals with my Dad. Pour is pitch black with a small tan head and decent lacing. Brown sugar, blueberries, tannic, oaky, cocoa, brown sugar, caramel, and grapey aroma. Taste is chocolate-covered blueberries, grapey, raspberries, cocoa, brown sugar, bready, some coconut, and dates with a tangy finish. Full mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Smooth and easy drinking, tastes like a full bodied wine with hints of chocolate.
Sweet, boozy, bourbon, chocolate, orange, vanilla, dark malt. Dark brown. Super complex and keeps coming at you long after you sip.

Aromas of butterscotch, fruit cake, brandy, candied orange, dark chocolate. Dark bronze with a fairly lasting, small, off-white head. A little sweet, pretty boozy, lots of caramel and chocolate, anf whiskey. Full bodied.
Aromas of roasty cocoa, warm vanilla, minor coconut, and sweet malt. Light brown head and dark brown body. Flavors of cocoa, berries, spice, light coconut and carmalized malt. Very smooth.

Pours a deep reddish black on tap with fluffy off-white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of big barrel notes that lend molasses, dark fruits, vanilla, and sweet chocolate. Taste is just as complex, big chocolate and brown sugar notes, fading to hints of caramel and dark fruit, then a slightly bittersweet roasty finish. Complex as all hell, amazing as you expect.

22. Thanks, J! Pours an opaque black with a dense and creamy light tan head that lasts. Big sweet nose showing chocolate, vanilla, coffee, molasses, coffee and other sweet notes. Sticky thick body not much carbonation. Chocolate vanilla coffee molasses and all the rest on the mid palate . long earthy sweet finish

Bottle (22 oz) shared at tasting by Julien Huxley, thanks! Reddish brown with a small bubbly brown head leaving little legs on the glass. Unsurprisingly, the aroma is rather boozy and combine loads of bourbon/vanilla features to toasted malts, roasted malts, toffee, caramel and dried fruits... its super rich but theres borderline too much going on... and the line is crossed with the taste wheres its too much for me. Bourbon, sweetness, vanilla, toffee, dried fruits, some straight-up boozy notes, roasted malts, toasted notes and all the usual suspects. While theres a ton going on, I wouldnt say its "multi-layered" as its a bit messy. Full body. Soft to moderate carbonation. Oily and rather thick mouthfeel. Hot and fruity finish. While I rather enjoyed my small sample, I already had more than enough. I think that good big bold beer can be "drinkable" - at least in small quantity, this isnt the case here. Not bad, but definitely not I would seek again especially considering the price.

Draft at Links Taproom in Chicago. Looks like a Belgian quad, dark reddish with limited khaki head. Nose is dark cherry, vanilla, leather, chocolate, bourbon. Taste is rich, complex, dark Belgian sweetness, brandied cherry, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Chewy and properly carbonated. Very, very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish brown with a thin offwhite head that leaves spotty lacing. Nose is of coconut, caramel and booze (some kirsch impressions even). Taste is of coconut, caramel, bourbon, light oxidized alcohol. Body is medium-full, carbonation moderate and while alcohol is present throughout all the experience it is never too much or hot. Pretty good, I just wish it was richer.

On draft at Stone Escondido. Dark red brown pour, with a beige head. Smooth milk chocolate, raisin, plum, vanilla, roasted bread, brown sugar, bourbon, and oak. Smooth and warming. I think this is one of the better years.

On tap at Hops and Pie poured a clear reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of toffee, fruitiness, Bourbon, dark chocolate, light oak and light vinous notes. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, bourbon, dried fruit, light cocoa and light oak with a smooth lingering bourbon finish.

Bottle form Craft Beer Cellar. Rich deep red brown pour with thin tan foam. Aroma is rich, tons of caramel, toasted notes, rich bourbon, boozy notes, vanilla. Taste is sweet, multi-layered, rich, bourbon, toasted notes, caramel. Palate is full bodied, boozy, rich and full. Good.

bottle shared by julienhuxley, thanks bro! pours unclear light brown, mahogany tint, with a small light beige cap, some retention and lacing. burnt caramel, bourbon, toffee vanilla, candies, booze, cotton candy, sweet toffee maltiness, molasses and buckwheat honey sweetness, spices. moderate carbonation, medium to full body - oily; sweetish-sticky, warming, boozy and bourbony-spicy finish. a tad overdone, as expected.

Bomber from GM Liquors. Nose is vanilla, bourbon, toffee, black raisins, and woody notes. Hazy dark brown with a small beige head. Flavor is moderately sweet, woody vanilla, bourbon, very light bitterness, finishing with hints of bitter, vanilla, and alcohol warmth. Probably the best version since 10 & 13.

Bottle from Beermongers. Pours a very dark brown hue that is really red a small beige head. A big really massive, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate nose. Big Stickee Monkey, bourbon, berries, oak, vanilla and toffee. Very smooth. Excellent brew. Simpler than past versions and in some ways more harmonious. Lovely big beer. 14% but very drinkable.

At Stone Escondido during the release event for this beer. Black beer with a nice lasting beige head. Caramel aroma, raisins, figs, toffee, roasted notes, licorice, vanilla notes, bourbon, brandy notes, cream, milk chocolate, plum notes, some biscuits. Caramel and chocolate flavor, raisins, figs, woody, bourbon notes, brandy, woody, vanilla, extremely well hidden alcohol, milk chocolate, biscuits, toffee, some roasted notes. I could probably go on with flavors all evening, this is crazy good. Full bodied and with all the good stuff coming back in the finish. Wow!
